I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help improve the capacity of 
Pacific developing member countries (DMCs) to develop and implement projects, with a view of 
enhancing the performance of the Pacific portfolio. The TA will provide support by (i) developing 
approaches for  country-  and/or  region-specific capacity  enhancement (short-  to  long-term), 
(ii) delivering targeted training programs and workshops, (iii) conducting technical audits and 
procurement reviews, and (iv) providing capacity reinforcement for specific projects.  
 
2.  The  TA  supports  operational  priority  6  (strengthening  governance  and  institutional 
capacity) of the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Strategy 2030,1 and is included in the regional 
operations business plan for the Pacific, 2020–2022.2 The TA will build on a previous ADB 
capacity development TA, Building Project Implementation Capacities in the Pacific.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Limited capacity environment in the Pacific. Seven of the 14 Pacific DMCs are 
classified as fragile and conflict-affected situations while the remainder share many of their 
characteristics.4 They  have  small  populations  and  limited  capacity,  and  are  dependent  on 
development partner assistance. As geographically dispersed and isolated countries, they are 
also vulnerable to climate change, natural hazards, and economic shocks. These features also 
provide a challenging environment for implementing projects in the Pacific. Limited capacity 
results in reliance on foreign consultants and workers. Government agencies require support to 
build  their  capacity  in  project  planning,  preparation,  and  implementation,  particularly  in 
procurement, contract management, financial management, social and environmental safeguards, 
project management, and asset management. Greater effort is required to fill these capacity gaps 
in Pacific island countries.  
 
4.  Lack of systematic training in developing member countries. The Pacific DMCs 
mainly receive ad hoc project management training provided by development partners in areas 
including  procurement,  social  and  environmental  safeguards,  and  financial  management. 
Government ownership of training is weak, as this is typically externally provided and not adapted 
to specific country needs. The lack of strategic, structured, and regular capacity building based 
on a needs assessment results in few opportunities for government staff to systematically develop 
their skills in a sustained manner. Staff turnover of those who have been trained is also an issue. 
 
5.  Innovation is essential. Travel restrictions related to the coronavirus disease (COVID-
19) pandemic have slowed down implementation of infrastructure development projects because 
of nonavailability or limited availability of supervision consultants in the field and the limited 
capacity  of  executing  and  implementing  agencies  to monitor  and  control  quality.  This  has 
highlighted the importance of finding innovative solutions to the challenges faced in the Pacific. 
Adoption of high-level technology (HLT) and innovations in construction methods and materials, 
quality supervision, and management information systems for efficient monitoring, are important

to achieve value-for-money in the infrastructure investments. To carry out quality monitoring and 
project management remotely, innovative measures that employ HLT are needed.  
 
6.  Poor  efficiency  and  sustainability weaken project  success.  According  to  ADB’s 
Independent Evaluation Department (IED), the percentage of highly successful or successful 
projects in Pacific DMCs evaluated during 2010–2019 varied from 42% to 71% (3-year moving 
average.5 The percentage during the three most recent cycles6 are as follows: 53% for 21 projects 
(2015–2017), 59% for 17 projects (2016–2018), and 42% for 19 projects (2017–2019). This data 
must be understood in light of the fact that the completed projects being evaluated over the 2010–
2017 period would have been designed around 10 years prior, and so do not necessarily reflect 
the current Pacific portfolio and the innovations in design and implementation that have occurred 
in the intervening 1–2 decades. However, what is significant is that the critical factors contributing 
to low success rates were sustainability and efficiency. The DMCs frequently do not have enough 
institutional capacity or financial resources to design, develop, and implement the sustainability 
components such as asset management systems, and operation and maintenance schedules.  
 
7.  A  number  of  factors  drive  the  efficiency  of  project  implementation. 
Project performance ratings in the first quarter of 2020 rated more than 40% of projects in the 
Pacific either “for attention” or “at risk.”7 Several factors contributed to these ratings, including 
weak  capacity  of  executing  and  implementing  agencies,  underperforming  contractors  and 
consultants,  absence  of  efficient  monitoring  systems,  and  the  quality  of  projects  at  entry. 
The 2019 Annual Portfolio Performance Report8 found for the Pacific, 38% of the projects 
committed in 2019 were design- or procurement-ready, compared with an ADB-wide average of 
83% design-ready and 50% procurement-ready.9  
 
8.  Historically, procurement has contributed to implementation delays. About 25% of 
procurement contract transactions had a processing time of 40 days or less, compared with an 
ADB-wide average of 67%. This can be partially attributed to the poor quality of bid documents 
and evaluation reports resulting from the low capacity of executing and implementing agencies. 
End-to-end procurement time in 2019 averaged 254 days for contracts of more than $10 million.10 
The complex country systems for approvals also add to the delays. However, the average 
implementation period for projects by ADB’s Pacific Department (PARD) that closed in 2019 was 
5.7 years, below the bank-wide average of 7.1 years, in both cases compared with a designed 
average implementation period at entry of 4.8 years.   
 
9.  Understanding of 2017 procurement policy still developing. In 2017, ADB approved 
the new procurement policy11 and procurement regulations for ADB borrowers. The policy and 
regulations require preparation of procurement plans based on full assessment of the needs and 
objectives of the borrower and describes the project activities to support them. The scope and 
details of the procurement plan take into account, and are proportional to, the relevant market, 
scale, risk, value and country circumstances, including when applicable, situations of urgent need 
of assistance or capacity constraints, and the specific economic, environmental, and social

objectives of the project. Guidance notes to prepare these strategic procurement plans (SPP) 
were issued in June 2018. Of projects approved by ADB in 2019 across all DMCs, 67% followed 
the 2017 procurement framework,12 and a few SPPs were prepared following the published 
guidelines. However, in the Pacific, the longer lead time in project development has meant 
approval of projects using the 2017 policy taking place from late-201913. The 2017 procurement 
framework allows flexibility in the procurement approaches, packaging, procurement methods; 
and emphasizes quality and value for money, but requires that executing and implementing 
agencies have greater procurement capacity  to prudently implement projects with fiduciary 
safeguards. Financial management is an area of particular capacity constraint. This requires 
support for DMCs’ capacity enhancement.   
 
10.  Lessons learned. In developing this TA, ADB has drawn lessons from past TA projects14 
and considered the recommendations of corporate reviews. The 2016 review of Medium-Term 
Framework  and  Action  Plan  for  capacity  development 15  committed  to  strengthen  the 
implementation of the Framework, promote effective HLT options, strengthen the quality-at-entry 
review process, and pursue capacity development support initiatives. The IED’s 2020 Annual 
Evaluation Review (footnote 5) recommends developing a more explicit and expanded public 
sector management capacity development program in relation to ADB investments, focusing on 
executing and implementing agencies, which is the intent of output 1. Complementing this, 
the 2019 Annual Portfolio Performance Report (footnote 8) recommends tailoring projects and 
programs to address country-specific training requirements and priorities that can be integrated 
into institutional development strategies. 
 
11.  Specific lessons that have been incorporated in the TA include: (i) building capacity in 
management for development results must go at the pace of the targeted organization, which can 
require longer time periods and flexibility in scheduling; (ii) planning implementation support 
requires long-term TA commitments to facilitate sustainable change; (iii) a sustained presence by 
ADB in Pacific DMCs is essential to provide strong logistical support to ADB field missions, 
promote  local  capacity  building,  and  facilitate  day-to-day  communication;  and  (iv) capacity 
development support for due diligence, project management, procurement, financial management, 
safeguards, and contract management is critical to support implementation of projects in the 
Pacific. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
12.  Initiatives to improve portfolio performance must target all aspects of the project cycle.16  
Measures for improving project performance include: (i) improving project readiness, (ii) providing 
extra layers of due diligence and risk management in projects, (iii) supporting the implementation 
of  the  2017  procurement  framework,  and  (iv)  strengthening  financial  management  and 
institutional capacity. The TA will support sustainable capacity enhancement initiatives based on 
country-specific  institutional  arrangements,  practices,  and  needs;  long  term-capacity 
reinforcements through consulting support; additional due diligence; and required technical audits

staff instructions, and guidance notes.

A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: quality of Pacific portfolio enhanced. The TA 
will have the following outcome: project development and implementation capacities in the Pacific 
improved.19  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
14.  Output 1: Strategies for country- and/or region-specific capacity enhancement 
(short-  to  long-term)  developed.  The  TA  will  conduct  country-  and/or  region-specific 
assessments of capacity gaps and develop targeted approaches for capacity enhancements in 
project  design,  project  implementation,  project  management,  and  financial  management. 
The assessments will identify capacity gaps, needs, and constraints of major stakeholders and 
potential executing and implementing agencies, including ministries, utilities, local contractors, 
and related industry players. These will inform the development of approaches for short-term and 
medium-  to  long-term  capacity  building  of  Pacific  DMCs  to  be  supported  under  output  2. 
The approaches  can  include  developing  accreditation  systems  in  procurement,  project 
management, and financial management; and exploring partnerships with regional institutions. 
  
15.  Output 2: Training programs and/or workshops delivered. Based on the results of 
assessments in output 1, training and workshops will be delivered to DMCs on developing and 
managing projects, including financial management to address identified issues. The topics and 
participants will depend on the results of the assessments produced under output 1. The TA also 
supports development of training material and resource persons. Workshops will be conducted 
on the implementation of ADB’s 2017 procurement framework and SPP. These will be project-
based and supported by sector, country, or subregion industry assessments. The workshops will 
be  undertaken  at  the  project  preparation  and  implementation  stages.  The participants  will 
comprise the staff of executing and implementing agencies. Online training modules will be 
developed, and online training will be conducted where appropriate. 
 
16.  Output 3: Technical audits and procurement reviews conducted. The TA will conduct 
annual technical audits and procurement reviews of selected complex projects in PARD’s portfolio, 
including for project readiness financing, to facilitate timely intervention and improvements in 
project implementation and ongoing and future related project design. The reviews will also help 
the executing and implementing agencies in revising the procurement plans to be fit-for-purpose 
procurement  approaches.  The  technical  audits  refer  to  all  aspects  of  project  design  and 
implementation, and address the constraints or delays a project is facing. 
 
17.  Output 4: Capacity reinforcement for specific projects provided. This output will 
support capacity reinforcements by specialists to address specific issues that arise during project 
implementation in key areas such as project management, procurement, contract management, 
use of HLT, and financial management. This support will not duplicate consulting services 
embedded in the scope of outputs 1–3, but will provide targeted interventions to address,

C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $5,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund ($3,685,000 TASF 6 and $1,315,000 TASF-other sources). 
The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. The governments of participating DMCs will 
provide counterpart support in the form of country data, counterpart staff (if needed), meeting 
rooms  as  required  for  consultants,  and  other  in-kind  contributions  as  agreed  during  TA 
implementation. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  ADB  will  be  the  executing  agency.  PARD  will  be  the  implementing  agency. 
PARD’s Portfolio, Results, and Quality Control Unit will serve as the principal focal point for the 
TA administration, responsible for the recruitment, supervision, and management of consultants 
as well as monitoring and evaluation of the outputs. The implementation arrangements are 
summarized in the following table.

20.  Consulting  services.  The  TA  will  require  an  estimated  145  person-months  of 
international and 135 person-months of national and regional consulting services. ADB will 
engage the consultants in accordance with the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from

6 
time to time) and its associated staff instructions.20 The Procurement, Portfolio, and Financial 
Management Department (PPFD) Framework Agreement21 of procurement consultants will be 
used for individual consultants recruitment, where appropriate, with the concurrence of PPFD. 
Firms will be selected using the (i) quality- and cost-based selection method with a 90:10 quality-
cost ratio to ensure quality of the complex scope, through a simplified technical proposal; and 
(ii) consultant  qualification  selection  method  for  technical  audits  and  procurement  reviews. 
Output-based and/or framework contracts will be considered for consulting services, where 
appropriate, with the concurrence of PPFD. Where possible, the use of fixed out-of-pocket 
expenses will be considered for administrative efficiency and to simplify the disbursement process.  
 
21.  ADB will procure nonconsulting services following the procurement staff instructions for 
staff undertaking procurement of goods, works, and services under ADB-administered TA. 
 
22.  The TA consultants will develop a management information and tracking system to record, 
manage, and track the activities and results of the TA project. Inputs will be coordinated with other 
development partners in the region to ensure complementarity, prevent duplication of efforts, and 
ensure consistent approaches to achieving long-term sustainability. 
 
23.  Coronavirus disease situation. With travel restrictions related to the pandemic expected 
to continue into the first half of 2021, the inputs of international consultants on the field will be 
constrained, posing challenges to TA implementation. Some of the measures to be taken to 
overcome these constraints include the involvement of the Pacific country offices, recruitment of 
national and/or regional consultants where appropriate, pairing remotely the national consultants 
with international consultants, and increased use of information and communication technology 
in TA implementation such as online missions, online training, and webinars.  
 
E.  Governance 
24.  The procurement risk is minimal since ADB will lead the consultant recruitment. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $5,000,000 on a grant basis for 
Enhancing Quality Portfolio Performance in the Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
